As expected, the narrative today from some has been that crypto created contagion in the banking sector. In reality, it was more the banking sector creating contagion in crypto here.

SVB collapse, for instance, was unrelated to crypto.
Silvergate and Signature probably more nuanced. Signature had about 20% crypto deposits I believe.
Seems like we need a consortium to come together to own a bank that will serve all of tech while taking less risk on deposits. Need a management team the OCC will approve as well.
Thx  for combatting FUD btw.

Depends on your definition but short answer is emphatically yes.

https://eriktorenberg.substack.com/p/what-does-the-gray-tribe-want

We over-hired in 2021 - it caused us to move slower not faster. In crypto it's never as good as it seems, and never as bad as it seems. In 2021, it was not as good as it seems, and right now it's nowhere near as bad as it seems.

We're getting more done with 3,500 people than we were with 5,000. More focused.

Waterworld with Kevin Costner got terrible reviews but I loved it as a kid and still think it's cool.

I've been enjoying going back and watching favorites from the 80's and 90's when I was growing up. Interview with the Vampire is a "bad" movie that I also love. Last of the Mohicans, etc.

Side note: a frequent topic with friends is why there aren't more tech positive films coming out of hollywood.

Most films today are "decel" and virtue signaling: villain is an evil tech CEO, social network, highlight tech blow up stories like Super Pumped or Theranos, etc.

The Martian was a rare film that put science/tech as the hero.

We need more positive stories on tech/AI/crypto, etc. Hollywood has a strange Marxist streak, as to many "elite" institutions today.

In the beginning I had a chip on my shoulder and just wanted to do something other people thought was important - desire to be recognized.

At some point it shifted, and my primary motivation is:
1. I'm a true believer in economic freedom, free markets, capitalism, sound money, etc - and crypto is best shot we have

2. I think tech is a force for good in the world
3. I love building things and learning new things. Being the CEO of a crypto company offers lots of opportunities to do both.

If I was on a deserted island, I would still build things and try to learn things. I can't help it (almost pathological).

Building companies scratches the same itch as video games like StarCraft II and Civilization. I find it even more fund to do those in real life (which is basically tech entrepreneurship) with the added bonus of it improves the world.
Side note: i had to quit those games cold turkey in my 20's to not let them take up too much of my time.

1. Stop coding and delegate sooner (held on to this too long)
2. Stop being conflict avoidant and accept you won't be liked by everyone - if you have conviction be clear with everyone up front. It's ok if some people don't like it.
3. Press is half fake - ignore it, or treat it like a game and work the system

Thx for noticing that! We're remote-first (which means no one has to come in, but we try to make great in-office experiences for people who want to, and we try to get all remote employees to an in person event at least once a quarter).

Remote-first has a been a win I think, and we're going to continue it.

Remote first is best at getting top people, and (i think) making them more productive (still gathering data on that). It makes culture and development harder, so we try to correct that with more in person events.

I think when the economy gets back to growth, we'll see more companies lean remote first again, as....

...its superpower is getting great people in a competitive hiring environment. Right now some companies are going back to in-office but I think that's in part to passively encourage some people to quit to reduce costs. When the economy goes back to growth I predict more remote-first.

Very open to it - I think we can and should see a greater % of transactions in crypto be private over time. Like the internet moving from HTTP to HTTPS.

I suspect the more likely path to adoption is to add optional private transactions to ETH, rather than a privacy-only chain/coin (which attracts bad actors).

Both super sharp, hardworking, genuinely good humans, friends. We should be grateful they are on team crypto and team human.

 has mellowed a little bit in his "old" age (mid-thirties), but still hyper competitive and crushes everyone in first-person shooters :)

I'll talk about the crypto industry and not Coinbase specifically here: the move to layer 2's as the default. Getting the average transaction in crypto to confirm in under 1 second for under 1 cent. It will unlock a next wave of utility. Like the internet moving from dialup to broadband.

I'm optimistic the U.S. will get it right - the U.S. always ends up in the right spot, but only after exhausting every other option. I think we may need to change out the current administration though. Gensler and Warren are actively trying to kill crypto, but they won't succeed.
They're painting outside the bounds of the law, and the courts are holding them accountable. They can do a lot of damage in the mean time, but crypto will outlast any administration or politician.

The great thing about the U.S. is the winds change every 4-8 years. In China, we could be stuck with the same bad person/policy for 30+ years.

History repeats https://newsletter.pessimistsarchive.org/p/joe-biden-kicked-off-the-encryption

After the Coinbase IPO (direct listing) I had some liquidity and time to think on the next decade. I 100% wanted to keep building Coinbase, as I think we're just getting started on progress toward economic freedom (I want to see crypto being used daily by 1B+ people).

But I also started thinking about underinvested areas where I could help do something unique. I hosted a series of dinners with the smartest people I could find in biotech, and epigenetic reprogramming kept coming...

...up as a topic. I started feeling about epigenetic reprogramming like I did about Bitcoin when I first encountered it: high potential, underinvested in. My friend Blake Byers and I connected with the (now) co-founders of NewLimit, Jacob and Greg, and the company was born...

Around that time I found out I was not crazy as two others epigenetic reprogramming companies came on the scene funded by Jeff Bezos and Sam Altman. I suspect it will be an exciting space. The next 10-20 years we could see a lot of progress in biotech, with humans living longer, and...

.ultimately accelerating evolution and changing what it means to be human.

My hope is that I can help many ambitious companies get off the ground in my lifetime that accelerate progress for humanity. This is part of why it's important to build resources, so you can allocate capital to ambitious and difficult projects.
I should talk to Patrick and John about this - good point!

I think it was partially innate for me, and a touch of aspergers helps. But I definitely feel quite stressed at times, and I think it's a muscle one can build.

Basically, push yourself 20% outside your comfort zone (not 200%) on a regular basis, until that is your new normal...

...Then repeat. There doesn't seem to be any limit to this as far as I can tell.

Plenty of items that would have stressed me out previously feel totally normal to me now (public speaking, upsetting people with difficult decisions, dealing with crises).

I still get nervous when firing people though - which bugs me.
Win our SEC case. Help grow https://standwithcrypto.org/. And get legislation passed.

I don't think crypto is a panacea, but yes I do think it will help with this.

Growth solves all problems (in companies, countries, etc). When countries stop growing, you see more internal division, and war with other countries.

Economic freedom is negatively correlated with war, I believe because it facilitates growth. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_Freedom_of_the_World

So TL;DR crypto is the best tool we have for sound money, free markets, global trade, property rights, etc - basically injecting good financial infrastructure...
...into the countries of the world. This will create growth, and reduce war/conflict (both internal and external).
Haha yes - you're welcome!
Stick with it through at least once crypto cycle to make sure the external noise isn't clouding your thinking.
